entry.title: The race is on to control the global supply chain for AI chips
entry.content:
ğŸ’¡

All content on this blog is intended solely for the purpose of learning English and is not meant to infringe on any copyrights. All translations and citations are used for educational and non-commercial purposes. This blog is publicly accessible and free, with no profit being made from its content.

If you believe that any content on this blog infringes on your copyright, please contact me at the following email address, and I will promptly remove the content in question after verification.

Thank you for your understanding and support.

Contact: public@neurocoda.com

Source: The race is on to control the global supply chain for AI chips

The Race is on to Control the Global Supply Chain for AI Chips ï½œ äº‰å¤ºå…¨çƒ AI èŠ¯ç‰‡ä¾›åº”é“¾æ§åˆ¶æƒçš„ç«èµ›å·²ç»å¼€å§‹

IMAGE: MIKE HADDAD

Jul 30th 2024

In 1958 Jack Kilby at Texas Instruments engineered a silicon chip with a single transistor. By 1965 Fairchild Semiconductor had learned how to make a piece of silicon with 50 of the things. As Gordon Moore, one of Fairchildâ€™s founders, observed that year, the number of transistors that could fit on a piece of silicon was doubling on a more or less annual basis.

åœ¨ 1958 å¹´ï¼ŒJack Kilbyåœ¨ Texas Instruments è®¾è®¡äº†ä¸€å—å¸¦æœ‰å•ä¸ªæ™¶ä½“ç®¡çš„ç¡…èŠ¯ç‰‡ã€‚åˆ°äº† 1965 å¹´ï¼ŒFairchild Semiconductor å·²ç»å­¦ä¼šå¦‚ä½•åœ¨ä¸€å—ç¡…ç‰‡ä¸Šåˆ¶é€  50 ä¸ªè¿™æ ·çš„æ™¶ä½“ç®¡ã€‚æ­£å¦‚ Fairchild Semiconductor çš„åˆ›å§‹äººä¹‹ä¸€ Gordon Moore åœ¨é‚£ä¸€å¹´è§‚å¯Ÿåˆ°çš„ï¼Œèƒ½å¤Ÿæ”¾ç½®åœ¨ä¸€å—ç¡…ç‰‡ä¸Šçš„æ™¶ä½“ç®¡æ•°é‡åŸºæœ¬ä¸Šæ¯å¹´éƒ½åœ¨ç¿»å€ã€‚

transistor n. æ™¶ä½“ç®¡

In 2023 Apple released the iPhone 15 Pro, powered by the a17 bionic chip, with 19bn transistors. The density of transistors has doubled 34 times over 56 years. That exponential progress, loosely referred to as Mooreâ€™s law, has been one of the engines of the computing revolution. As transistors became smaller they got cheaper (more on a chip) and faster, allowing all the hand-held supercomputing wonders of today. But the sheer number of numbers that ai programs need to crunch has been stretching Mooreâ€™s law to its limits.

åœ¨ 2023 å¹´ï¼Œè‹¹æœå‘å¸ƒäº†æ­è½½ A17 ä»¿ç”ŸèŠ¯ç‰‡çš„ iPhone 15 Proï¼Œè¯¥èŠ¯ç‰‡æ‹¥æœ‰ 190 äº¿ä¸ªæ™¶ä½“ç®¡ã€‚æ™¶ä½“ç®¡çš„å¯†åº¦åœ¨56å¹´é—´ç¿»å€äº†34æ¬¡ã€‚è¿™ç§æŒ‡æ•°çº§çš„è¿›æ­¥ï¼Œè¢«å®½æ³›åœ°ç§°ä¸ºæ‘©å°”å®šå¾‹ï¼Œä¸€ç›´æ˜¯è®¡ç®—é©å‘½çš„å¼•æ“ä¹‹ä¸€ã€‚éšç€æ™¶ä½“ç®¡å˜å¾—æ›´å°ï¼Œå®ƒä»¬å˜å¾—æ›´ä¾¿å®œï¼ˆæ¯ä¸ªèŠ¯ç‰‡ä¸Šçš„æ•°é‡æ›´å¤šï¼‰ä¸”æ›´å¿«ï¼Œä»è€Œå®ç°äº†å½“ä»Šæ‰€æœ‰æ‰‹æŒè¶…çº§è®¡ç®—çš„å¥‡è¿¹ã€‚ç„¶è€Œï¼Œäººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½ç¨‹åºéœ€è¦å¤„ç†çš„å¤§é‡æ•°æ®å·²ç»å°†æ‘©å°”å®šå¾‹æ¨åˆ°äº†æé™ã€‚

bionic adj. ä»¿ç”Ÿçš„
density n. æµ“å¯†ï¼›å¯†åº¦
exponential adj. å¹‚çš„ï¼›æŒ‡æ•°çš„
loosely adv. å®½æ¾çš„ï¼›æ¾æ•£çš„
sheer adj. åè¶³çš„ï¼›çº¯ç²¹çš„ï¼›é™¡å³­çš„
crunch v. å˜å±å˜å±åœ°åŠ¨ ï½œ n. å˜å±å£°ï¼›è‰°éš¾å±€é¢ï¼›å±æ€¥æƒ…å†µ

Sources: Epoch AI; FreeingEnergy

The neural networks found in almost all modern AI need to be trained in order to ascertain the right â€œweightsâ€ to give their billions, sometimes trillions, of internal connections. These weights are stored in the form of matrices, and training the model involves manipulating those matrices, using maths.Â Two matricesâ€”sets of numbers arrayed in rows and columnsâ€”are used to generate a third such set; each number in that third set is produced by multiplying together all the numbers in a row in the first set with all those in a column of the second and then adding them all up. When the matrices are large, with thousands or tens of thousands of rows and columns, and need to be multiplied again and again as training goes on, the number of times individual numbers have to be multiplied and added together becomes huge.

å‡ ä¹æ‰€æœ‰ç°ä»£ AI ä¸­çš„ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œéƒ½éœ€è¦ç»è¿‡è®­ç»ƒï¼Œä»¥ç¡®å®šå…¶æ•°åäº¿ç”šè‡³æ•°ä¸‡äº¿å†…éƒ¨è¿æ¥çš„æ­£ç¡®â€œæƒé‡â€ã€‚è¿™äº›æƒé‡ä»¥çŸ©é˜µçš„å½¢å¼å­˜å‚¨ï¼Œè®­ç»ƒæ¨¡å‹æ¶‰åŠä½¿ç”¨æ•°å­¦æ“ä½œè¿™äº›çŸ©é˜µã€‚ä¸¤ä¸ªçŸ©é˜µâ€”â€”å³æŒ‰è¡Œå’Œåˆ—æ’åˆ—çš„ä¸€ç»„æ•°å­—â€”â€”è¢«ç”¨æ¥ç”Ÿæˆç¬¬ä¸‰ä¸ªè¿™æ ·çš„é›†åˆï¼›ç¬¬ä¸‰ä¸ªé›†åˆä¸­çš„æ¯ä¸ªæ•°å­—éƒ½æ˜¯é€šè¿‡å°†ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªé›†åˆä¸­çš„ä¸€è¡Œæ‰€æœ‰æ•°å­—ä¸ç¬¬äºŒä¸ªé›†åˆä¸­çš„ä¸€åˆ—æ‰€æœ‰æ•°å­—ç›¸ä¹˜ï¼Œç„¶åå°†å®ƒä»¬å…¨éƒ¨ç›¸åŠ å¾—åˆ°çš„ã€‚å½“çŸ©é˜µå¾ˆå¤§ï¼ŒåŒ…å«æˆåƒä¸Šä¸‡è¡Œå’Œåˆ—ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”åœ¨è®­ç»ƒè¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­éœ€è¦åå¤ç›¸ä¹˜æ—¶ï¼Œå•ä¸ªæ•°å­—éœ€è¦ç›¸ä¹˜å’Œç›¸åŠ çš„æ¬¡æ•°å°±ä¼šå˜å¾—éå¸¸åºå¤§ã€‚

ascertain v. æŸ¥æ˜ï¼›å¼„æ¸…ï¼›ç¡®å®š
manipulation n. æ“çºµï¼›æ“ä½œï¼›å¤„ç†

In this series on artificial intelligence

  1. A short history of AI
  2. Mining the net
  3. The matrix multiplications*

The training of neural nets, though, is not the only objective that requires lightning-fast matrix multiplication. So does the production of high-quality video images that make computer games fun to play: and 25 years ago that was a far larger market. To serve it Nvidia, a chipmaker, pioneered the design of a new sort of chip, the graphics-processing unit (gpu), on which transistors were laid out and connected in a way that let them do lots of matrix multiplications at once. When applied to ai, this was not their only advantage over the central processing units (CPUs) used for most applications: they allowed larger batches of training data to be used. They also ate up a lot less energy.

ç„¶è€Œï¼Œç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œçš„è®­ç»ƒå¹¶ä¸æ˜¯å”¯ä¸€éœ€è¦æå¿«çŸ©é˜µä¹˜æ³•çš„ç›®æ ‡ã€‚é«˜è´¨é‡è§†é¢‘å›¾åƒçš„ç”Ÿæˆä¹Ÿæ˜¯å¦‚æ­¤ï¼Œè¿™ä½¿å¾—ç”µè„‘æ¸¸æˆæ›´å…·å¯ç©æ€§ï¼šè€Œ25å¹´å‰ï¼Œè¿™æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ›´å¤§çš„å¸‚åœºã€‚ä¸ºäº†æœåŠ¡è¿™ä¸€å¸‚åœºï¼ŒèŠ¯ç‰‡åˆ¶é€ å•†è‹±ä¼Ÿè¾¾ï¼ˆNvidiaï¼‰å¼€åˆ›äº†ä¸€ç§æ–°å‹èŠ¯ç‰‡çš„è®¾è®¡ï¼Œå³å›¾å½¢å¤„ç†å•å…ƒï¼ˆGPUï¼‰ï¼Œå…¶æ™¶ä½“ç®¡çš„å¸ƒå±€å’Œè¿æ¥æ–¹å¼ä½¿å…¶èƒ½å¤ŸåŒæ—¶è¿›è¡Œå¤§é‡çŸ©é˜µä¹˜æ³•ã€‚å½“åº”ç”¨äºäººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½æ—¶ï¼Œè¿™å¹¶ä¸æ˜¯å®ƒä»¬ç›¸å¯¹äºç”¨äºå¤§å¤šæ•°åº”ç”¨çš„ä¸­å¤®å¤„ç†å•å…ƒï¼ˆCPUï¼‰çš„å”¯ä¸€ä¼˜åŠ¿ï¼šå®ƒä»¬å…è®¸ä½¿ç”¨æ›´å¤§æ‰¹é‡çš„è®­ç»ƒæ•°æ®ã€‚æ­¤å¤–ï¼Œå®ƒä»¬ä¹Ÿæ¶ˆè€—æ›´å°‘çš„èƒ½é‡ã€‚

objective n. ç›®æ ‡

Training AlexNet, the model which ushered in the age of â€œdeep learningâ€ in 2012, meant assigning weights to 60m internal connections. That required Â floating-point operations (flop); each flop is broadly equivalent to adding or multiplying two numbers.Â Until then, that much computation would have been out of the question. Even in 2012, using the best CPUs would not just have required a lot more time and energy but also simplifying the design. The system that trained AlexNet did all its phenomenal FLOPping with just two GPUs.

è®­ç»ƒ AlexNetï¼ˆåœ¨ 2012 å¹´å¼€å¯ â€œæ·±åº¦å­¦ä¹ â€ æ—¶ä»£çš„æ¨¡å‹ï¼‰æ„å‘³ç€è¦ä¸º 6000 ä¸‡ä¸ªå†…éƒ¨è¿æ¥åˆ†é…æƒé‡ã€‚è¿™éœ€è¦ æ¬¡æµ®ç‚¹è¿ç®—ï¼ˆflopï¼‰ã€‚æ¯æ¬¡ flop å¤§è‡´ç›¸å½“äºå¯¹ä¸¤ä¸ªæ•°å­—è¿›è¡ŒåŠ æ³•æˆ–ä¹˜æ³•è¿ç®—ã€‚åœ¨é‚£ä¹‹å‰ï¼Œå¦‚æ­¤å¤§é‡çš„è®¡ç®—æ˜¯ä¸å¯æƒ³è±¡çš„ã€‚å³ä½¿åœ¨ 2012 å¹´ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨æœ€å¥½çš„ CPU ä¸ä»…éœ€è¦æ›´å¤šçš„æ—¶é—´å’Œèƒ½æºï¼Œè¿˜éœ€è¦ç®€åŒ–è®¾è®¡ã€‚è€Œè®­ç»ƒ AlexNet çš„ç³»ç»Ÿä»…ç”¨ä¸¤å— GPU å°±å®Œæˆäº†æ‰€æœ‰åºå¤§çš„æµ®ç‚¹è¿ç®—ã€‚

usher n. æ¥å¾…å‘˜ï¼›é—¨æˆ¿ ï½œ v. å¼•é¢†ï¼›æ‹›å¾…ï¼›åšæ‹›å¾…å‘˜

A recent report from Georgetown Universityâ€™s Centre for Emerging Technology says GPUs remain 10-100 times more cost-efficient and up to 1,000 times faster than cpus when used for training models. Their availability was what made the deep-learning boom possible. Large language models (LLMs), though, have pushed the demand for calculation even further.

Transformers Are Go ï½œ Transformer å‡†å¤‡å°±ç»ª

In 2018 Alec Radford, a researcher at OpenAI, developed a generative pre-trained transformer, or gpt, using the â€œtransformerâ€ approach described by researchers at Google the year before. He and his colleagues found the modelâ€™s ability to predict the next word in a sentence could reliably be improved by adding training data or computing power. Getting better at predicting the next word in a sentence is no guarantee a model will get better at real-world tasks. But so far the trend embodied in those â€œscaling lawsâ€ has held up.

As a result llms have grown larger. Epoch ai, a research outfit, estimates that training gpt-4 in 2022 required flop, 40m times as many as were used for AlexNet a decade earlier, and cost about 5 \times 10^{25}$ flop. These totals are incomprehensibly big, comparable to all the stars in all the galaxies of the observable universe, or the drops of water in the Pacific Ocean.

In the past the solution to excessive needs for computation has been a modicum of patience. Wait a few years and Mooreâ€™s law will provide by putting even more, even faster transistors onto every chip. But Mooreâ€™s law has run out of steam. With individual transistors now just tens of nanometres (billions of a metre) wide, it is harder to provide regular jumps in performance. Chipmakers are still working to make transistors smaller, and are even stacking them up vertically to squeeze more of them onto chips. But the era in which performance increased steadily, while power consumption fell, is over.

As Mooreâ€™s law has slowed down and the desire to build ever-bigger models has taken off, the answer has been not faster chips but simply more chips. Insiders suggest gpt-4 was trained on 25,000 of Nvidiaâ€™s a100 gpus, clustered together to reduce the loss of time and energy that occurs when moving data between chips.

Much of the 100bn cluster in Wisconsin called Stargate. Some in Silicon Valley talk of a $1trn cluster within the decade. Such infrastructure needs a lot of energy. In March Amazon bought a data centre next door to a nuclear power plant that can supply it with a gigawatt of power.

The investment does not all go on GPUs and the power they draw. Once a model is trained, it has to be used. Putting a query to an AI system typically requires roughly the square root of the amount of computing used to train it. But that can still be a lot of calculation. For gpt-3, which required flop to train, a typical â€œinferenceâ€ can take flop. Chips known as fpgas and asics, tailored for inference, can help make running ai models more efficient than using gpus.

Nevertheless, it is Nvidia that has done best out of the boom. The company is now worth 10bn to develop). The company also benefits from owning the software framework used to program its chips, called cuda, which is something like the industry standard. And it has a dominant position in the networking equipment used to tie the chips together.

Competitors claim to see some weaknesses. Rodrigo Liang of SambaNova Systems, another chip firm, says that Nvidiaâ€™s postage-stamp-size chips have several disadvantages which can be traced back to their original uses in gaming.Â A particularly big one is their limited capacity for moving data on and off (as an entire model will not fit on one gpu).

Cerebras, another competitor, markets a â€œwafer scaleâ€ processor that is 21.5cm across. Where GPUs now contain tens of thousands of separate â€œcoresâ€ running calculations at the same time, this behemoth has almost a million. Among the advantages the company claims is that, calculation-for-calculation, it uses only half as much energy as Nvidiaâ€™s best chip. Google has devised its own easily customised â€œtensor-processing unitâ€ (tpu) which can be used for both training and inference. Its Gemini 1.5 ai model is able to ingest eight times as much data at a time as gpt-4, partly because of that bespoke silicon.

The huge and growing value of cutting-edge gpus has been seized on for geopolitical leverage. Though the chip industry is global, a small number of significant choke-points control access to its ai-enabling heights. Nvidiaâ€™s chips are designed in America. The worldâ€™s most advanced lithography machines, which etch designs into silicon through which electrons flow, are all made by asml, a Dutch firm worth 800bn, and Americaâ€™s Intel have access to this tool. And for many other smaller items of equipment the pattern continues, with Japan being the other main country in the mix.

These choke-points have made it possible for the American government to enact harsh and effective controls on the export of advanced chips to China. As a result the Chinese are investing hundreds of billions of dollars to create their own chip supply chain. Most analysts believe China is still years behind in this quest, but because of big investments by companies such as Huawei, it has coped with export controls much better than America expected.

Source: AI firms will soon exhaust most of the internetâ€™s data

AI Firms Will soon Exhaust Most of the internetâ€™s Data AI å…¬å¸å°†å¾ˆå¿«ç”¨å°½äº’è”ç½‘ä¸­çš„æ•°æ®

IMAGE: MIKE HADDAD

Jul 23rd 2024

In 2006 fei-fei li, then at the University of Illinois, now at Stanford University, saw how mining the internet might help to transform ai research. Linguistic research had identified 80,000 â€œnoun synonym setsâ€, or synsets: groups of synonyms that described the same sort of thing. The billions of images on the internet, Dr Li reckoned, must offer hundreds of examples of each synset. Assemble enough of them and you would have an ai training resource far beyond anything the field had ever seen. â€œA lot of people are paying attention to models,â€ she said. â€œLetâ€™s pay attention to data.â€ The result was ImageNet.

åœ¨ 2006 å¹´ï¼Œå°±è¯»äº Illinois å¤§å­¦ï¼ˆç°åœ¨çš„ Stanford å¤§å­¦ï¼‰çš„ fei-fei li çœ‹åˆ°äº†æŒ–æ˜äº’è”ç½‘ä¿¡æ¯ä¹Ÿè®¸èƒ½æ”¹å˜äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½ç ”ç©¶ã€‚è¯­è¨€å­¦ç ”ç©¶å·²ç»æ˜ç¡®äº† 80,000 ä¸ª â€œåæ¬¡åŒä¹‰è¯é›†åˆâ€æˆ–è€…è¯´åŒä¹‰è¯ï¼ˆæè¿°åŒä¸€ç±»äº‹ç‰©çš„è¯ç»„ï¼‰ã€‚Li åšå£«ä¼°è®¡ï¼Œäº’è”ç½‘ä¸Šçš„æ•°åäº¿å¼ å›¾ç‰‡ä¸€å®šæä¾›äº†æ•°ç™¾ä¸ªæ¯ä¸ªåŒä¹‰è¯é›†çš„ä¾‹å­ã€‚æ”¶é›†è¶³å¤Ÿå¤šçš„è¿™æ ·çš„èµ„æºï¼Œä½ å°†æ‹¥æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªè¿œè¿œè¶…å‡ºè¯¥é¢†åŸŸä»¥å¾€ä»»ä½•èµ„æºçš„äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½è®­ç»ƒèµ„æºã€‚â€œå¾ˆå¤šäººéƒ½åœ¨å…³æ³¨æ¨¡å‹ï¼Œâ€å¥¹è¯´ï¼Œâ€œæˆ‘ä»¬åº”è¯¥å…³æ³¨æ•°æ®ã€‚â€ ç»“æœå°±åœ¨ ImageNetã€‚

synonym n. åŒä¹‰è¯
synset n. åŒä¹‰è¯é›†
assemble v. è£…é…ï¼›é›†åˆ

In this series on artificial intelligence

  1. A short history of AI
  2. Mining the net*

The internet provided not only the images, but also the resources for labelling them. Once search engines had delivered pictures of what they took to be dogs, cats, chairs or whatever, these images were inspected and annotated by humans recruited through Mechanical Turk, a crowdsourcing service provided by Amazon which allows people to earn money by doing mundane tasks. The result was a database of millions of curated, verified images. It was through using parts of ImageNet for its training that, in 2012, a program called AlexNet demonstrated the remarkable potential of â€œdeep learningâ€â€”that is to say, of neural networks with many more layers than had previously been used. This was the beginning of the ai boom, and of a labelling industry designed to provide it with training data.

äº’è”ç½‘ä¸ä»…æä¾›å›¾åƒï¼Œè¿˜æä¾›æ ‡è®°å›¾åƒçš„èµ„æºã€‚ä¸€æ—¦æœç´¢å¼•æ“æä¾›äº†ä»–ä»¬è®¤ä¸ºæ˜¯ç‹—ã€çŒ«ã€æ¤…å­æˆ–å…¶ä»–ä¸œè¥¿çš„å›¾ç‰‡ï¼Œè¿™äº›å›¾åƒå°±ä¼šç”±é€šè¿‡ Mechanical Turk æ‹›å‹Ÿçš„äººå‘˜è¿›è¡Œæ£€æŸ¥å’Œæ³¨é‡Šã€‚Mechanical Turk æ˜¯äºšé©¬é€Šæä¾›çš„ä¼—åŒ…æœåŠ¡ï¼Œå…è®¸äººä»¬é€šè¿‡å®Œæˆæ—¥å¸¸ä»»åŠ¡æ¥èµšé’±ã€‚æœ€ç»ˆï¼Œä»–ä»¬åˆ›å»ºäº†ä¸€ä¸ªåŒ…å«æ•°ç™¾ä¸‡å¼ ç»è¿‡ç­›é€‰å’ŒéªŒè¯çš„å›¾åƒçš„æ•°æ®åº“ã€‚2012 å¹´ï¼Œä¸€ä¸ªåä¸º AlexNet çš„é¡¹ç›®é€šè¿‡ä½¿ç”¨ ImageNet çš„éƒ¨åˆ†å†…å®¹è¿›è¡Œè®­ç»ƒï¼Œå±•ç¤ºäº†â€œæ·±åº¦å­¦ä¹ â€çš„å·¨å¤§æ½œåŠ›â€”â€”ä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯è¯´ï¼Œç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œçš„å±‚æ•°æ¯”ä»¥å‰ä½¿ç”¨çš„è¦å¤šå¾—å¤šã€‚è¿™æ˜¯äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½ç¹è£çš„å¼€å§‹ï¼Œä¹Ÿæ˜¯æ ‡æ³¨è¡Œä¸šï¼ˆæä¾›è®­ç»ƒæ•°æ®ï¼‰çš„å¼€å§‹ã€‚

take to be è®¤ä¸ºæ˜¯ï¼›æŠŠ â€¦ å½“ä½œ

crowdsourcing n. ä¼—åŒ…
curate n. å‰¯ç‰§å¸ˆï¼›åŠ©ç†ç‰§å¸ˆ ï½œ v. ç»„ç»‡ï¼›æ‹…ä»»é¦†é•¿
that is to say ä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯è¯´

The later development of large language models (llms) also depended on internet data, but in a different way. The classic training exercise for an llm is not predicting what word best describes the contents of an image; it is predicting what a word cut from a piece of text is, on the basis of the other words around it.

åæ¥çš„å¤§è¯­è¨€æ¨¡å‹ï¼ˆLLMsï¼‰çš„å¼€å‘åŒæ ·ä¾èµ–äºäº’è”ç½‘çš„æ•°æ®ï¼Œä½†æ‰€ä½¿ç”¨çš„æ–¹å¼ä¸åŒã€‚LLM çš„ä¼ ç»Ÿçš„è®­ç»ƒä¸æ˜¯é¢„æµ‹å“ªä¸ªå•è¯æœ€èƒ½æè¿°å›¾ç‰‡çš„å†…å®¹ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯åœ¨å®ƒå‘¨å›´çš„å…¶ä»–å•è¯çš„åŸºç¡€ä¸Šæ¥é¢„æµ‹è¿™ä¸€æ®µä»æ–‡æœ¬ä¸­åˆ‡å‡ºçš„å•è¯æ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆã€‚

on the basis of åŸºäºâ€¦ ; åœ¨ â€¦ çš„åŸºç¡€ä¸Š

In this sort of training there is no need for labelled and curated data; the system can blank out words, take guesses and grade its answers in a process known as â€œself-supervised trainingâ€. There is, though, a need for copious data. The more text the system is given to train on, the better it gets. Given that the internet offers hundreds of trillions of words of text, it became to llms what aeons of carbon randomly deposited in sediments have been to modern industry: something to be refined into miraculous fuel.

åœ¨è¿™ç§è®­ç»ƒæ–¹å¼ä¸­ä¸éœ€è¦æ ‡è®°å¹¶å½’ç±»åçš„æ•°æ®ã€‚è¯¥ç³»ç»Ÿå¯ä»¥åˆ é™¤å•è¯ã€è¿›è¡ŒçŒœæµ‹å¹¶å¯¹ç­”æ¡ˆè¿›è¡Œè¯„åˆ†ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªè¿‡ç¨‹è¢«ç§°ä¸ºâ€œè‡ªæˆ‘ç›‘ç£è®­ç»ƒâ€ã€‚ä¸è¿‡ï¼Œè¿™éœ€è¦å¤§é‡çš„æ•°æ®ã€‚ç”¨äºè®­ç»ƒç³»ç»Ÿçš„æ–‡æœ¬è¶Šå¤šï¼Œç³»ç»Ÿçš„æ•ˆæœå°±è¶Šå¥½ã€‚é‰´äºäº’è”ç½‘æä¾›äº†æ•°ç™¾ä¸‡äº¿ä¸ªå•è¯çš„æ–‡æœ¬ï¼Œå®ƒå¯¹äº LLMs æ¥è¯´ï¼Œå°±å¦‚åŒåœ¨æ¼«é•¿æ—¶æœŸä¸­éšæœºæ²‰ç§¯åˆ°æ²‰ç§¯ç‰©ä¸­çš„å¤§é‡ç¢³å¯¹äºç°ä»£å·¥ä¸šä¸€æ ·ï¼šå¯ä»¥æç‚¼æˆä¸å¯æ€è®®çš„ç‡ƒæ–™ã€‚

blank out v. å–æ¶ˆ
copious adj. å¤§é‡çš„ï¼›ä¸°å¯Œçš„
aeon n. æ¼«é•¿çš„æ—¶æœŸï¼›æ°¸ä¸–ï¼›åƒä¸‡å¹´
sediment n. æ²‰æ·€ç‰©ï¼›æ²‰ç§¯ç‰©
refine v. ç²¾ç‚¼ï¼›æ”¹è¿›
miraculous adj. å¥‡è¿¹èˆ¬çš„ï¼›ä¸å¯æ€è®®çš„ï¼›ç¥å¥‡çš„

Common Crawl, an archive of much of the open internet including 50bn web pages, became widely used in ai research. Newer models supplemented it with data from more and more sources, such as Books3, a widely used compilation of thousands of books. But the machinesâ€™ appetites for text have grown at a rate the internet cannot match. Epoch ai, a research firm, estimates that, by 2028, the stock of high-quality textual data on the internet will all have been used. In the industry this is known as the â€œdata wallâ€. How to deal with this wall is one of aiâ€™s great looming questions, and perhaps the one most likely to slow its progress.

Common Crawl æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªåŒ…å« 500 äº¿ä¸ªç½‘é¡µçš„å¼€æ”¾äº’è”ç½‘æ¡£æ¡ˆåº“ï¼Œåœ¨äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½ç ”ç©¶ä¸­å¾—åˆ°äº†å¹¿æ³›çš„åº”ç”¨ã€‚è¾ƒæ–°çš„æ¨¡å‹è¡¥å……äº†æ¥è‡ªè¶Šæ¥è¶Šå¤šæ¥æºçš„æ•°æ®ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚ Books3ï¼Œå®ƒæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªè¢«å¹¿æ³›ä½¿ç”¨çš„ç”±æ•°åƒæœ¬ä¹¦æ±‡ç¼–å‡ºæ¥çš„ã€‚ä½†æœºå™¨å¯¹æ–‡æœ¬çš„èƒƒå£å¢é•¿é€Ÿåº¦æ˜¯äº’è”ç½‘æ— æ³•æ¯”æ‹Ÿçš„ã€‚ç ”ç©¶å…¬å¸ Epoch ai ä¼°è®¡ï¼Œåˆ° 2028 å¹´ï¼Œäº’è”ç½‘ä¸Šé«˜è´¨é‡çš„æ–‡æœ¬åº“å°†å…¨éƒ¨è¢«ä½¿ç”¨ã€‚ä¸šå†…ç§°ä¹‹ä¸ºâ€œæ•°æ®å¢™â€ã€‚å¦‚ä½•å¤„ç†è¿™å µå¢™æ˜¯äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½é¢ä¸´çš„è¿«åˆ‡çš„é—®é¢˜ä¹‹ä¸€ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”è¿™ä¹Ÿæ˜¯æœ€æœ‰å¯èƒ½å‡ç¼“å…¶è¿›æ­¥çš„é—®é¢˜ã€‚

crawl v. çˆ¬è¡Œ
supplement n. è¡¥å……ç‰©ï¼›é™„å½•ï¼›é™„åŠ è´¹ ï½œ v. è¡¥å……ï¼›å¢åŠ 
compilation n. ç¼–è¾‘ï¼›ç¼–æ’°ï¼›æ±‡ç¼–ç‰©
loom v. è¿«è¿‘ï¼›éšçº¦å¯è§ ï½œ n. ç»‡å¸ƒæœºï¼›è‹¥éšè‹¥ç°
looming adj. é€¼è¿‘çš„ï¼›è¿«åœ¨çœ‰ç«çš„ ï½œ v-ing. è¿«è¿‘

Source: EpochAI

One approach is to focus on data quality rather than quantity. ai labs do not simply train their models on the entire internet. They filter and sequence data to maximise how much their models learn. Naveen Rao of Databricks, an ai firm, says that this is the â€œmain differentiatorâ€ between ai models on the market. â€œTrue informationâ€ about the world obviously matters; so does lots of â€œreasoningâ€. That makes academic textbooks, for example, especially valuable. But setting the balance between data sources remains something of a dark art. What is more, the ordering in which the system encounters different types of data matters too. Lump all the data on one topic, like maths, at the end of the training process, and your model may become specialised at maths but forget some other concepts.

ä¸€ä¸ªè§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆæ˜¯ä¸“æ³¨äºæ•°æ®çš„è´¨é‡è€Œä¸æ˜¯æ•°é‡ã€‚äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½å®éªŒå®¤å¹¶ä¸åªæ˜¯åœ¨æ•´ä¸ªäº’è”ç½‘ä¸Šè®­ç»ƒä»–ä»¬çš„æ¨¡å‹ã€‚ä»–ä»¬è¿‡æ»¤å¹¶æ’åºæ•°æ®ä»¥æœ€å¤§åŒ–ä»–ä»¬çš„æ¨¡å‹çš„å­¦ä¹ æ•ˆæœã€‚ä¸€å®¶åä¸º Naveen Rao of Databricks çš„ AI å…¬å¸è¯´è¿™å°±æ˜¯å¸‚é¢ä¸Šçš„æ¨¡å‹ â€œä¸»è¦çš„åŒºåˆ«â€ã€‚å…³äºä¸–ç•Œçš„ â€œçœŸå®ä¿¡æ¯â€ æ˜¾ç„¶æ˜¯é‡è¦çš„ï¼Œå¾ˆå¤šâ€œæ¨ç†â€ä¹Ÿæ˜¯å¦‚æ­¤ã€‚æ¯”å¦‚ï¼Œè¿™ä½¿å¾—å­¦æœ¯æ•™ææ˜¾å¾—æ›´æœ‰ä»·å€¼ã€‚ä½†åœ¨æ•°æ®æºä¹‹é—´è®¾å®šå¹³è¡¡ä»ç„¶æ˜¯ä¸€é—¨ â€œé»‘æš—è‰ºæœ¯â€ã€‚æ­¤å¤–ï¼Œç³»ç»Ÿå¤„ç†ä¸åŒä¸åŒç±»å‹çš„æ•°æ®çš„é¡ºåºä¹Ÿå¾ˆé‡è¦ï¼Œåœ¨è®­ç»ƒè¿‡ç¨‹ç»“æŸæ—¶å°†æ‰€æœ‰æ•°æ®é›†ä¸­åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªä¸»é¢˜ä¸Šï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚æ•°å­¦ï¼Œä½ çš„æ¨¡å‹å¯èƒ½ä¼šä¸“æ³¨äºæ•°å­¦ï¼Œä½†ä¼šå¿˜è®°å…¶ä»–ä¸€äº›æ¦‚å¿µã€‚

differentiator n. åŒºåˆ«ï¼›å¾®åˆ†å™¨
textbook n. æ•™æï¼›æ•™ç§‘ä¹¦ï¼›è¯¾æœ¬

lump n. å—ï¼›è‚¿å—ï¼›éš†èµ· ï½œ v. æ··åœ¨ä¸€èµ·ï¼›ç»“å—ï¼›å‹‰å¼ºæ¥å—

These considerations can get even more complex when the data are not just on different subjects but in different forms. In part because of the lack of new textual data, leading models like Openaiâ€™s gpt-4o and Googleâ€™s Gemini are now let loose on image, video and audio files as well as text during their self-supervised learning. Training on video is hardest given how dense with data points video files are. Current models typically look at a subset of frames to simplify things.

å½“æ•°æ®ä¸ä»…æ¶‰åŠä¸åŒçš„ä¸»é¢˜è€Œä¸”å…·æœ‰ä¸åŒçš„å½¢å¼æ—¶ï¼Œè¿™äº›è€ƒè™‘ä¼šå˜å¾—æ›´åŠ å¤æ‚ã€‚éƒ¨åˆ†åŸå› æ˜¯ç¼ºä¹æ–°çš„æ–‡æœ¬æ•°æ®ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥åƒ OpenAI çš„ GPT-4o å’Œ Google çš„ Gemini è¿™äº›é¢†å…ˆæ¨¡å‹ç°åœ¨åœ¨è‡ªç›‘ç£å­¦ä¹ è¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­ï¼Œä¸ä»…å±€é™äºæ–‡æœ¬ï¼Œè¿˜è¢«å®¹è®¸å­¦ä¹ å›¾åƒã€è§†é¢‘å’ŒéŸ³é¢‘æ–‡ä»¶ã€‚ç”±äºè§†é¢‘æ–‡ä»¶ä¸­æ•°æ®ç‚¹çš„å¯†åº¦å¾ˆå¤§ï¼Œè§†é¢‘è®­ç»ƒæ˜¯æœ€å›°éš¾çš„ï¼Œå½“å‰çš„æ¨¡å‹é€šå¸¸é€šè¿‡æŸ¥çœ‹å¸§çš„å­é›†ä»¥ç®€åŒ–æ­¤è¿‡ç¨‹ã€‚

dense adj. å¯†é›†çš„ï¼›ç¨ å¯†çš„ï¼›æ„šé’çš„

Whatever models are used, ownership is increasingly recognised as an issue. The material used in training llms is often copyrighted and used without consent from, or payment to, the rights holders. Some ai models peep behind paywalls. Model creators claim this sort of thing falls under the â€œfair useâ€ exemption in American copyright law. ai models should be allowed to read copyrighted material when they learn, just as humans can, they say. But as Benedict Evans, a technology analyst, has put it, â€œa difference in scaleâ€ can lead to â€œa difference in principleâ€.

æ— è®ºä½¿ç”¨å“ªç§æ¨¡å‹ï¼Œç‰ˆæƒè¶Šæ¥è¶Šè¢«è§†ä¸ºä¸€ä¸ªé—®é¢˜ã€‚ç”¨äºè®­ç»ƒ LLMs çš„ææ–™é€šå¸¸å—ç‰ˆæƒä¿æŠ¤ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”åœ¨æœªç»ç‰ˆæƒæ‰€æœ‰è€…åŒæ„æˆ–æœªå‘å…¶ä»˜è´¹çš„æƒ…å†µä¸‹ä½¿ç”¨ã€‚ä¸€äº›äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½æ¨¡å‹åœ¨ä»˜è´¹å¢™åçª¥è§†ã€‚æ¨¡å‹åˆ›å»ºè€…å£°ç§°ï¼Œè¿™ç§äº‹æƒ…å±äºç¾å›½ç‰ˆæƒæ³•çš„â€œåˆç†ä½¿ç”¨â€è±å…ã€‚ä»–ä»¬è¯´ï¼Œäººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½æ¨¡å‹åœ¨å­¦ä¹ æ—¶åº”è¯¥è¢«å…è®¸é˜…è¯»å—ç‰ˆæƒä¿æŠ¤çš„ææ–™ï¼Œå°±åƒäººç±»ä¸€æ ·ã€‚ä½†æ­£å¦‚æŠ€æœ¯åˆ†æå¸ˆ Benedict Evans æ‰€è¯´ï¼Œâ€œè§„æ¨¡ä¸Šçš„å·®å¼‚â€å¯èƒ½å¯¼è‡´â€œåŸåˆ™ä¸Šçš„å·®å¼‚â€ã€‚

peep v. å·çœ‹ ï½œ n. çª¥è§†
exemption n. è±å…ï¼›å…é™¤
scale n. è§„æ¨¡ï¼›ç­‰çº§ï¼›åˆ»åº¦ ï½œ v. æ”¹å˜ â€¦ çš„å¤§å°ï¼› æ”€ç™»
fall under phrase. è¢«å½’å…¥ï¼›å—åˆ°ï¼ˆå½±å“ï¼‰ï¼›è½åœ¨ â€¦ ä¸‹é¢

The Best Labellers Can Earn up to $100 an Hour æœ€å¥½çš„æ ‡ç­¾å¸ˆæ¯å°æ—¶èƒ½èµš 100 ç¾åˆ€

Different rights holders are taking different tactics. Getty Images has sued Stability ai, an image-generation firm, for unauthorised use of its image store. The New York Times has sued Openai and Microsoft for copyright infringement of millions of articles. Other papers have struck deals to license their content. News Corp, owner of the Wall Street Journal, signed a deal worth $250m over five years. (The Economist has not taken a position on its relationship with ai firms.) Other sources of text and video are doing the same. Stack Overflow, a coding help-site, Reddit, a social-media site, and X (formerly Twitter) are now charging for access to their content for training.

ä¸åŒçš„ç‰ˆæƒæŒæœ‰è€…é‡‡å–äº†ä¸åŒçš„ç­–ç•¥ã€‚Getty Images èµ·è¯‰å›¾ç‰‡ç”Ÿæˆå…¬å¸ Stability ai æœªç»æˆæƒä½¿ç”¨å…¶å›¾ç‰‡åº“ã€‚The New York Times èµ·è¯‰ Openai å’Œå¾®è½¯ä¾µçŠ¯æ•°ç™¾ä¸‡ç¯‡æ–‡ç« çš„ç‰ˆæƒã€‚å…¶ä»–æŠ¥çº¸å·²è¾¾æˆå†…å®¹æˆæƒåè®®ã€‚Wall Street Journal çš„æ¯å…¬å¸ News Corp ç­¾ç½²äº†ä¸€ä»½ä¸ºæœŸäº”å¹´ã€ä»·å€¼ 2.5 äº¿ç¾å…ƒçš„åè®®ã€‚ï¼ˆThe Economist å°šæœªå°±å…¶ä¸äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½å…¬å¸çš„å…³ç³»è¡¨æ€ã€‚ï¼‰å…¶ä»–æ–‡æœ¬å’Œè§†é¢‘æ¥æºä¹Ÿåœ¨åšåŒæ ·çš„äº‹æƒ…ã€‚ç¼–ç¨‹å¸®åŠ©ç½‘ç«™ Stack Overflowã€ç¤¾äº¤åª’ä½“ç½‘ç«™ Reddit å’Œ Xï¼ˆä»¥å‰ç§°ä¸º Twitterï¼‰ç°åœ¨éƒ½é€šè¿‡èµ·å†…å®¹è®­ç»ƒæ”¶è´¹ã€‚

tactics n. ç­–ç•¥ï¼›æˆ˜æœ¯
sue v. èµ·è¯‰ï¼›æ§å‘Šï¼›è¯·æ±‚
infringement n. è¿åï¼ˆæ³•è§„ã€è§„ç« åˆ¶åº¦ç­‰ï¼‰ï¼›ä¾µçŠ¯ï¼ˆåˆæ³•æƒç›Šï¼‰

The situation differs between jurisdictions. Japan and Israel have a permissive stance to promote their ai industries. The European Union has no generic â€œfair useâ€ concept, so could prove stricter. Where markets are set up, different types of data will command different prices: models will need access to timely information from the real world to stay up to date.

ä¸åŒå¸æ³•ç®¡è¾–åŒºçš„æƒ…å†µæœ‰æ‰€ä¸åŒã€‚Japan å’Œ Israel å¯¹ AI è¡Œä¸šå‘ˆå¼€å‘æ€åº¦ã€‚European Union æ²¡æœ‰é€šç”¨çš„ â€œåˆç†ä½¿ç”¨â€ æ¦‚å¿µï¼Œå› æ­¤å¯èƒ½ä¼šæ›´åŠ ä¸¥æ ¼ã€‚åœ¨å¸‚åœºå»ºç«‹çš„åœ°æ–¹ï¼Œä¸åŒç±»å‹çš„æ•°æ®å°†ä¼šæœ‰ä¸åŒçš„ä»·æ ¼ï¼šæ¨¡å‹éœ€è¦è·å–æ¥è‡ªç°å®ä¸–ç•Œçš„åŠæ—¶ä¿¡æ¯æ‰èƒ½ä¿æŒæœ€æ–°çŠ¶æ€ã€‚

jurisdiction n. ç®¡è¾–æƒï¼›å¸æ³•æƒï¼›è£åˆ¤æƒï¼›ç®¡è¾–èŒƒå›´
permissive adj. æ”¾ä»»çš„ï¼›çºµå®¹çš„ï¼›è®¸å¯çš„
stance n. ç«™å§¿
generic adj. ä¸€èˆ¬çš„ï¼›æ™®é€šçš„ï¼›é€šç”¨çš„
set up phrase. å»ºç«‹ï¼›åˆ›ç«‹ï¼›è®¾ç«‹ï¼›æå‡º
timely adj. é€‚æ—¶çš„ï¼›åŠæ—¶çš„

Model capabilities can also be improved when the version produced by self-supervised learning, known as the pre-trained version, is refined through additional data in post-training. â€œSupervised fine-tuningâ€, for example, involves feeding a model question-and-answer pairs collected or handcrafted by humans. This teaches models what good answers look like. â€œReinforcement-learning from human feedbackâ€ (rlhf), on the other hand, tells them if the answer satisfied the questioner (a subtly different matter).

å½“é€šè¿‡è‡ªæˆ‘ç›‘ç£å­¦ä¹ äº§ç”Ÿçš„ç‰ˆæœ¬ï¼ˆç§°ä¸ºé¢„è®­ç»ƒç‰ˆæœ¬ï¼‰åœ¨ post-training ä¸­é€šè¿‡é¢å¤–çš„æ•°æ®è¿›è¡Œå®Œå–„æ—¶ï¼Œæ¨¡å‹èƒ½åŠ›ä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥å¾—åˆ°æé«˜ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œâ€œSupervised fine-tuningâ€æ¶‰åŠå‘æ¨¡å‹æä¾›ç”±äººç±»æ”¶é›†æˆ–æ‰‹å·¥åˆ¶ä½œçš„é—®ç­”å¯¹ï¼Œè¿™æ•™ä¼šæ¨¡å‹ä»€ä¹ˆæ˜¯å¥½çš„ç­”æ¡ˆã€‚å¦ä¸€æ–¹é¢ï¼Œâ€œä»äººç±»åé¦ˆä¸­è¿›è¡Œå¼ºåŒ–å­¦ä¹ â€ï¼ˆrlhfï¼‰ä¼šå‘Šè¯‰æ¨¡å‹ç­”æ¡ˆæ˜¯å¦è®©æé—®è€…æ»¡æ„ï¼ˆä¸€ä¸ªç•¥æœ‰ä¸åŒçš„é—®é¢˜ï¼‰ã€‚

reinforcement n. å¢å¼ºï¼›å¼ºåŒ–ç‰©
subtly adv. å·§å¦™åœ°ï¼›å¾®å¦™åœ°ï¼›éšçº¦åœ°

In rlhf users give a model feedback on the quality of its outputs, which are then used to tweak the modelâ€™s parameters, or â€œweightsâ€. User interactions with chatbots, such as a thumbs-up or -down, are especially useful for rlhf. This creates what techies call a â€œdata flywheelâ€, in which more users lead to more data which feeds back into tuning a better model. ai startups are keenly watching what types of questions users ask their models, and then collecting data to tune their models on those topics.

åœ¨ rlhf ä¸­ï¼Œç”¨æˆ·å‘æ¨¡å‹åé¦ˆå…¶è¾“å‡ºçš„è´¨é‡ï¼Œç„¶ååˆ©ç”¨è¿™äº›åé¦ˆæ¥è°ƒæ•´æ¨¡å‹çš„å‚æ•°æˆ–â€œæƒé‡â€ã€‚ç”¨æˆ·ä¸èŠå¤©æœºå™¨äººçš„äº¤äº’ï¼ˆä¾‹å¦‚ç«–èµ·å¤§æ‹‡æŒ‡æˆ–å€’ç«–èµ·å¤§æ‹‡æŒ‡ï¼‰å¯¹äº rlhf ç‰¹åˆ«æœ‰ç”¨ã€‚è¿™å°±äº§ç”Ÿäº†æŠ€æœ¯äººå‘˜æ‰€è¯´çš„ â€œæ•°æ®é£è½®â€ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­æ›´å¤šçš„ç”¨æˆ·ä¼šå¸¦æ¥æ›´å¤šçš„æ•°æ®ï¼Œè¿™äº›æ•°æ®ä¼šåé¦ˆåˆ°è°ƒæ•´æ›´å¥½çš„æ¨¡å‹ã€‚äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½åˆåˆ›å…¬å¸æ­£åœ¨æ•é”åœ°è§‚å¯Ÿç”¨æˆ·å‘ä»–ä»¬çš„æ¨¡å‹æå‡ºä»€ä¹ˆç±»å‹çš„é—®é¢˜ï¼Œç„¶åæ”¶é›†æ•°æ®æ¥é’ˆå¯¹è¿™äº›ä¸»é¢˜è°ƒæ•´ä»–ä»¬çš„æ¨¡å‹ã€‚

tweak v. æ‹§ï¼›æ‰­ ï½œ n. æ‹§ï¼›æ‰­ï¼›å¾®è°ƒ
parameter n. å‚æ•°ï¼›å‚é‡ï¼›å†³å®šå› ç´ ï¼›ç•Œé™
flywheel n. é£è½®
techie n. æŠ€æœ¯äººå‘˜
keenly adv. æ•é”åœ°ï¼›å¼ºçƒˆåœ°

Scale it up æ‰©å¤§è§„æ¨¡

As pre-training data on the internet dry up, post-training is more important. Labelling companies such as Scale ai and Surge ai earn hundreds of millions of dollars a year collecting post-training data. Scale recently raised 14bn valuation. Things have moved on from the Mechanical Turk days: the best labellers earn up to $100 an hour. But, though post-training helps produce better models and is sufficient for many commercial applications, it is ultimately incremental.

éšç€äº’è”ç½‘ä¸Šçš„ pre-training æ•°æ®æ¯ç«­ï¼Œpost-training å˜å¾—æ›´åŠ é‡è¦ã€‚æ ‡ç­¾å…¬å¸ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚ Scale ai å’Œ Surge ai ç­‰æ¯å¹´é€šè¿‡æ”¶é›† post-training æ•°æ®èµšå–æ•°äº¿ç¾å…ƒã€‚Scale æœ€è¿‘ä»¥ 140 äº¿ç¾å…ƒçš„ä¼°å€¼ç­¹é›†äº† 10 äº¿ç¾å…ƒã€‚äº‹æƒ…å·²ç»ä» Mechanical Turk æ—¶ä»£å‘ç”Ÿäº†å˜åŒ–ï¼šæœ€å¥½çš„æ ‡ç­¾å¸ˆæ¯å°æ—¶æœ€å¤šå¯èµš 100 ç¾å…ƒã€‚ä½†æ˜¯ï¼Œå°½ç®¡ post-training æœ‰åŠ©äºç”Ÿæˆæ›´å¥½çš„æ¨¡å‹å¹¶ä¸”è¶³ä»¥æ»¡è¶³è®¸å¤šå•†ä¸šåº”ç”¨çš„éœ€æ±‚ï¼Œä½†å®ƒç»ˆç©¶æ˜¯é€æ­¥çš„ã€‚

dry up phrase. å¹²æ¶¸ï¼›æ¯ç«­
valuation n. è¯„ä¼°ï¼›è¯„ä»·ï¼›ä¼°å€¼
ultimately adv. æœ€ç»ˆï¼›å½’æ ¹ç»“åº•ï¼›æ ¹æœ¬ä¸Š
incremental adj. å¢é•¿çš„ï¼›å¢åŠ çš„

Rather than pushing the data wall back bit by bit, another solution would be to jump over it entirely. One approach is to use synthetic data, which are machine-created and therefore limitless. AlphaGo Zero, a model produced by DeepMind, a Google subsidiary, is a good example. The companyâ€™s first successful Go-playing model had been trained using data on millions of moves from amateur games. AlphaGo Zero used no pre-existing data. Instead it learned Go by playing 4.9m matches against itself over three days, noting the winning strategies. That â€œreinforcement learningâ€ taught it how to respond to its opponentâ€™s moves by simulating a large number of possible responses and choosing the one with the best chance of winning.

å¦ä¸€ç§è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆæ˜¯å®Œå…¨è·³è¿‡æ•°æ®å¢™ï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯ä¸€ç‚¹ä¸€ç‚¹åœ°æ¨å€’å®ƒã€‚ä¸€ç§æ–¹æ³•æ˜¯ä½¿ç”¨åˆæˆæ•°æ®ï¼Œè¿™äº›æ•°æ®æ˜¯æœºå™¨åˆ›å»ºçš„ï¼Œå› æ­¤æ˜¯æ— é™çš„ã€‚è°·æ­Œå­å…¬å¸ DeepMind åˆ¶ä½œçš„æ¨¡å‹ AlphaGo Zero å°±æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå¾ˆå¥½çš„ä¾‹å­ã€‚è¯¥å…¬å¸ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªæˆåŠŸçš„å›´æ£‹æ¸¸æˆæ¨¡å‹æ˜¯ä½¿ç”¨æ•°ç™¾ä¸‡ä¸ªä¸šä½™æ¯”èµ›çš„æ•°æ®è¿›è¡Œè®­ç»ƒçš„ã€‚AlphaGo Zero æ²¡æœ‰ä½¿ç”¨ä»»ä½•é¢„å…ˆå­˜åœ¨çš„æ•°æ®ã€‚ç›¸åï¼Œå®ƒé€šè¿‡åœ¨ä¸‰å¤©å†…ä¸è‡ªå·±è¿›è¡Œ 490 ä¸‡åœºæ¯”èµ›æ¥å­¦ä¹ å›´æ£‹ï¼Œå¹¶è®°å½•è·èƒœç­–ç•¥ã€‚è¿™ç§ â€œå¼ºåŒ–å­¦ä¹ â€ æ•™ä¼šäº†å®ƒå¦‚ä½•é€šè¿‡æ¨¡æ‹Ÿå¤§é‡å¯èƒ½çš„å“åº”å¹¶é€‰æ‹©æœ€æœ‰å¯èƒ½è·èƒœçš„ååº”æ¥å“åº”å¯¹æ‰‹çš„åŠ¨ä½œã€‚

synthetic adj. åˆæˆçš„ï¼›äººé€ çš„ï¼›ç»¼åˆçš„
subsidiary adj. è¾…åŠ©çš„ï¼›é™„å±çš„ï¼›æ¬¡è¦çš„ ï½œ n. é™„å±äº‹ç‰©ï¼›é™„å±å…¬å¸

A similar approach could be used for llms writing, say, a maths proof, step-by-step. An llm might build up an answer by first generating many first steps. A separate â€œhelperâ€ ai, trained on data from human experts to judge quality, would identify which was best and worth building on. Such ai-produced feedback is a form of synthetic data, and can be used to further train the first model. Eventually you might have a higher-quality answer than if the llm answered in one go, and an improved llm to boot. This ability to improve the quality of output by taking more time to think is like the slower, deliberative â€œsystem 2â€ thinking in humans, as described in a recent talk by Andrej Karpathy, a co-founder of Openai. Currently, llms employ â€œsystem 1â€ thinking, generating a response without deliberation, similar to a humanâ€™s reflexive response.

ç›¸ä¼¼çš„æ–¹æ³•å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨åœ¨ LLMs çš„å†™ä½œï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚ï¼Œé€æ­¥ç¼–å†™æ•°å­¦è¯æ˜ã€‚ä¸€ä¸ª LLM å¯èƒ½é€šè¿‡é¦–å…ˆç”Ÿæˆè®¸å¤šåˆå§‹æ­¥éª¤å»ºç«‹ç­”æ¡ˆï¼Œä¸€ä¸ªå•ç‹¬çš„ â€œhelperâ€ AIï¼ˆç”±äººç±»ä¸“å®¶çš„æ•°æ®è¿›è¡Œè®­ç»ƒï¼‰æ¥åˆ¤æ–­å…¶è´¨é‡ï¼Œä»¥ç¡®å®šå“ªä¸ªæ˜¯æœ€å¥½çš„ï¼Œå€¼å¾—æ„å»ºçš„ã€‚è¿™ç§äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½äº§ç”Ÿçš„åé¦ˆæ˜¯ä¸€ç§åˆæˆæ•°æ®çš„ï¼Œå¯ä»¥ç”¨æ¥è¿›ä¸€æ­¥è®­ç»ƒç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªæ¨¡å‹ã€‚æœ€ç»ˆï¼Œæ‚¨å¯èƒ½ä¼šä¸€æ¬¡æ€§å°±å¾—åˆ°æ›´é«˜è´¨é‡çš„ç­”æ¡ˆï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”è¿˜ä¼šå¾—åˆ°ä¸€ä¸ªæ”¹è¿›çš„ LLMã€‚è¿™ç§é€šè¿‡èŠ±æ›´å¤šæ—¶é—´æ€è€ƒæ¥æé«˜äº§å‡ºè´¨é‡çš„èƒ½åŠ›ç±»ä¼¼äºäººç±»è¾ƒæ…¢ã€æ·±æ€ç†Ÿè™‘çš„â€œç³»ç»Ÿ 2â€æ€ç»´ï¼Œæ­£å¦‚ Openai è”åˆåˆ›å§‹äºº Andrej Karpathy åœ¨æœ€è¿‘çš„ä¸€æ¬¡æ¼”è®²ä¸­æ‰€æè¿°çš„é‚£æ ·ã€‚ç›®å‰ï¼ŒLLM é‡‡ç”¨â€œç³»ç»Ÿ 1â€æ€ç»´ï¼Œæ— éœ€æ·±æ€ç†Ÿè™‘å³å¯åšå‡ºååº”ï¼Œç±»ä¼¼äºäººç±»çš„åå°„æ€§ååº”ã€‚

reflexive adj. æ¡ä»¶åå°„çš„

The difficulty is extending the approach to settings like health care or education. In gaming, there is a clear definition of winning and it is easier to collect data on whether a move is advantageous. Elsewhere it is trickier. Data on what is a â€œgoodâ€ decision are typically collected from experts. But that is costly, takes time and is only a patchy solution. And how do you know if a particular expert is correct?

å›°éš¾åœ¨äºå°†è¿™ç§æ–¹æ³•æ‰©å±•åˆ°åŒ»ç–—ä¿å¥æˆ–æ•™è‚²ç­‰é¢†åŸŸã€‚åœ¨æ¸¸æˆä¸­ï¼Œèƒœåˆ©æœ‰æ˜ç¡®çš„å®šä¹‰ï¼Œæ”¶é›†æœ‰å…³æŸä¸€ä¸¾åŠ¨æ˜¯å¦æœ‰åˆ©çš„æ•°æ®æ›´å®¹æ˜“ã€‚åœ¨å…¶ä»–åœ°æ–¹ï¼Œè¿™æ›´æ£˜æ‰‹ã€‚æœ‰å…³ä»€ä¹ˆæ˜¯â€œå¥½â€å†³å®šçš„æ•°æ®é€šå¸¸æ˜¯ä»ä¸“å®¶é‚£é‡Œæ”¶é›†çš„ã€‚ä½†è¿™ç§æ–¹æ³•æˆæœ¬é«˜æ˜‚ï¼Œè€—æ—¶é•¿ï¼Œè€Œä¸”åªæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªä¸å®Œæ•´çš„è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆã€‚ä½ å¦‚ä½•çŸ¥é“æŸä½ä¸“å®¶æ˜¯å¦æ­£ç¡®ï¼Ÿ

advantageous adj. æœ‰åˆ©çš„ï¼›æœ‰å¥½å¤„çš„
tricky adj. éš¾åŠçš„ï¼›æ£˜æ‰‹çš„ï¼›ç‹¡çŒ¾çš„ï¼›è¯¡è®¡å¤šç«¯çš„
patchy adj. æœ‰è¡¥ä¸çš„ï¼›æ—¶å¥½æ—¶åçš„

It is clear that access to more dataâ€”whether culled from specialist sources, generated synthetically or provided by human expertsâ€”is key to maintaining rapid progress in AI. Like oilfields, the most accessible data reserves have been depleted. The challenge now is to find new onesâ€”or sustainable alternatives. â– 

æ˜¾ç„¶ï¼Œè·å–æ›´å¤šæ•°æ®ï¼ˆæ— è®ºæ˜¯ä»ä¸“ä¸šæ¥æºç­›é€‰ã€åˆæˆè¿˜æ˜¯ç”±äººç±»ä¸“å®¶æä¾›ï¼‰æ˜¯ä¿æŒäººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½å¿«é€Ÿå‘å±•çš„å…³é”®ã€‚å°±åƒæ²¹ç”°ä¸€æ ·ï¼Œæœ€å®¹æ˜“è·å–çš„æ•°æ®å‚¨å¤‡å·²ç»æ¯ç«­ã€‚ç°åœ¨çš„æŒ‘æˆ˜æ˜¯å¯»æ‰¾æ–°çš„æ•°æ®å‚¨å¤‡æˆ–å¯æŒç»­çš„æ›¿ä»£å“ã€‚â– 

cull v. æ‹£é€‰ï¼›é‡‡é›†
sustainable adj. å¯å®¹å¿çš„ï¼›å¯æ”¯æŒçš„ï¼›å¯æŒç»­çš„

entry.title: A short history of AI
entry.content:
ğŸ’¡

Source: A short history of AI

A short History of AI ä¸€åˆ™ç®€çŸ­çš„ AI å†å²

IMAGE: MIKE HADDAD

Jul 16th 2024

Over the summer of 1956 a small but illustrious group gathered at Dartmouth College in New Hampshire; it included Claude Shannon, the begetter of information theory, and Herb Simon, the only person ever to win both the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences awarded by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences and the Turing Award awarded by the Association for Computing Machinery. They had been called together by a young researcher, John McCarthy, who wanted to discuss â€œhow to make machines use language, form abstractions and conceptsâ€ and â€œsolve kinds of problems now reserved for humansâ€. It was the first academic gathering devoted to what McCarthy dubbed â€œartificial intelligenceâ€. And it set a template for the fieldâ€™s next 60-odd years in coming up with no advances on a par with its ambitions.

1956 å¹´å¤å¤©ï¼Œä¸€ä¸ªæ°å‡ºçš„å°å›¢ä½“èšé›†åœ¨ New Hampshire çš„ Dartmouth Collegeï¼›åŒ…å«ä¿¡æ¯è®ºçš„åˆ›å§‹äºº Claude Shannonï¼Œä»¥åŠè‡³ä»Šå”¯ä¸€ä¸€ä½åŒæ—¶è·å¾—ç‘å…¸çš‡å®¶ç§‘å­¦é™¢æˆäºˆçš„ç»æµå­¦çš„ Nobel Memorial Prize å’Œ ç”± ACM æˆäºˆ Turing Award çš„ Herb Simonã€‚ä»–ä»¬è¢«ä¸€ä¸ªå¹´è½»çš„å­¦è€… John McCarthy å·å¬åœ¨ä¸€èµ·ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªå¹´è½»çš„å­¦è€…æƒ³è¦è®¨è®º â€œå¦‚ä½•è®©æœºå™¨ä½¿ç”¨è¯­è¨€ã€å½¢æˆæŠ½è±¡å’Œæ¦‚å¿µâ€ å’Œ â€œè§£å†³ç›®å‰äººç±»æ‰€ä¿ç•™çš„é—®é¢˜â€ã€‚è¿™æ˜¯ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªä¸“é—¨è®¨è®º McCarthy æ‰€ç§°çš„ â€œäººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½â€ çš„å­¦æœ¯èšä¼šï¼Œä¸ºè¯¥é¢†åŸŸæ¥ä¸‹æ¥çš„å¤§çº¦å…­åå¤šå¹´å¥ å®šäº†æ¨¡æ¿ï¼Œå³ä½¿è¿™äº›å¹´æœªèƒ½å–å¾—ä¸å…¶é›„å¿ƒç›¸åŒ¹é…çš„çªç ´æ€§è¿›å±•ã€‚

over the summer of è¡¨ç¤ºåœ¨æŸä¸ªç‰¹å®šå¹´ä»½çš„å¤å¤©æœŸé—´å‘ç”Ÿçš„äº‹æƒ…ã€‚å®ƒé€šå¸¸ç”¨æ¥æè¿°ä¸€æ®µæ—¶é—´å†…çš„æ´»åŠ¨ã€å˜åŒ–æˆ–äº‹ä»¶ã€‚
illustrious adj. è‘—åçš„ï¼›æ°å‡ºçš„
begetter n. ç”Ÿäº§è€…
swedish adj. ç‘å…¸çš„ï¼›ç‘å…¸äººçš„ï¼›ç‘å…¸è¯­çš„ ï½œ n. ç‘å…¸è¯ï¼› ç‘å…¸äºº
machinery n. æœºæ¢°è£…ç½®ï¼›æœºæ¢°ï¼ˆæ€»ç§°ï¼‰
dub v. èµ·ç»°å·ï¼›æŠŠâ€¦ç§°ä¸ºï¼›é…éŸ³
devoted to phrase. è‡´åŠ›äº
-odd è¡¨ç¤ºå¤§çº¦çš„æ•°é‡ï¼Œä¸ç²¾ç¡®ä½†æ¥è¿‘

In this series on artificial intelligence

  1. A short history of AI*
  2. Running out of data
  3. Controlling the chip supply

The Dartmouth meeting did not mark the beginning of scientific inquiry into machines which could think like people. Alan Turing, for whom the Turing prize is named, wondered about it; so did John von Neumann, an inspiration to McCarthy. By 1956 there were already a number of approaches to the issue; historians think one of the reasons McCarthy coined the term artificial intelligence, later AI, for his project was that it was broad enough to encompass them all, keeping open the question of which might be best. Some researchers favoured systems based on combining facts about the world with axioms like those of geometry and symbolic logic so as to infer appropriate responses; others preferred building systems in which the probability of one thing depended on the constantly updated probabilities of many others.

The following decades saw much intellectual ferment and argument on the topic, but by the 1980s there was wide agreement on the way forward: â€œexpert systemsâ€ which used symbolic logic to capture and apply the best of human know-how. The Japanese government, in particular, threw its weight behind the idea of such systems and the hardware they might need. But for the most part such systems proved too inflexible to cope with the messiness of the real world. By the late 1980s AI had fallen into disrepute, a byword for overpromising and underdelivering. Those researchers still in the field started to shun the term.

It was from one of those pockets of perseverance that todayâ€™s boom was born. As the rudiments of the way in which brain cellsâ€”a type of neuronâ€”work were pieced together in the 1940s, computer scientists began to wonder if machines could be wired up the same way. In a biological brain there are connections between neurons which allow activity in one to trigger or suppress activity in another; what one neuron does depends on what the other neurons connected to it are doing. A first attempt to model this in the lab (by Marvin Minsky, a Dartmouth attendee) used hardware to model networks of neurons. Since then, layers of interconnected neurons have been simulated in software.

These artificial neural networks are not programmed using explicit rules; instead, they â€œlearnâ€ by being exposed to lots of examples. During this training the strength of the connections between the neurons (known as â€œweightsâ€) are repeatedly adjusted so that, eventually, a given input produces an appropriate output. Minsky himself abandoned the idea, but others took it forward. By the early 1990s neural networks had been trained to do things like help sort the post by recognising handwritten numbers. Researchers thought adding more layers of neurons might allow more sophisticated achievements. But it also made the systems run much more slowly.

A new sort of computer hardware provided a way around the problem. Its potential was dramatically demonstrated in 2009, when researchers at Stanford University increased the speed at which a neural net could run 70-fold, using a gaming PC in their dorm room. This was possible because, as well as the â€œcentral processing unitâ€ (cpu) found in all pcs, this one also had a â€œgraphics processing unitâ€ (gpu) to create game worlds on screen. And the gpu was designed in a way suited to running the neural-network code.

Coupling that hardware speed-up with more efficient training algorithms meant that networks with millions of connections could be trained in a reasonable time; neural networks could handle bigger inputs and, crucially, be given more layers. These â€œdeeperâ€ networks turned out to be far more capable.

The power of this new approach, which had come to be known as â€œdeep learningâ€, became apparent in the ImageNet Challenge of 2012. Image-recognition systems competing in the challenge were provided with a database of more than a million labelled image files. For any given word, such as â€œdogâ€ or â€œcatâ€, the database contained several hundred photos. Image-recognition systems would be trained, using these examples, to â€œmapâ€ input, in the form of images, onto output in the form of one-word descriptions. The systems were then challenged to produce such descriptions when fed previously unseen test images. In 2012 a team led by Geoff Hinton, then at the University of Toronto, used deep learning to achieve an accuracy of 85%. It was instantly recognised as a breakthrough.

By 2015 almost everyone in the image-recognition field was using deep learning, and the winning accuracy at the ImageNet Challenge had reached 96%â€”better than the average human score. Deep learning was also being applied to a host of other â€œproblemsâ€¦reserved for humansâ€ which could be reduced to the mapping of one type of thing onto another: speech recognition (mapping sound to text), face-recognition (mapping faces to names) and translation.

In all these applications the huge amounts of data that could be accessed through the internet were vital to success; what was more, the number of people using the internet spoke to the possibility of large markets. And the bigger (ie, deeper) the networks were made, and the more training data they were given, the more their performance improved.

the moreâ€¦the more è¡¨è¾¾ä¸¤è€…ä¹‹é—´çš„ç›¸äº’å…³ç³»æˆ–å˜åŒ–ã€‚è¿™ä¸ªç»“æ„è¡¨ç¤ºéšç€ä¸€ä¸ªäº‹æƒ…ï¼ˆæˆ–çŠ¶æ€ï¼‰å¢åŠ æˆ–å¢å¼ºï¼Œå¦ä¸€ä¸ªäº‹æƒ…ï¼ˆæˆ–çŠ¶æ€ï¼‰ä¹Ÿéšä¹‹å¢åŠ æˆ–å¢å¼ºã€‚é€šå¸¸ç”¨äºæè¿°ä¸¤ä¸ªå˜é‡ä¹‹é—´çš„æ­£ç›¸å…³å…³ç³»

Deep learning was soon being deployed in all kinds of new products and services. Voice-driven devices such as Amazonâ€™s Alexa appeared. Online transcription services became useful. Web browsers offered automatic translations. Saying such things were enabled by AI started to sound cool, rather than embarrassing, though it was also a bit redundant; nearly every technology referred to as AI then and now actually relies on deep learning under the bonnet.

æ·±åº¦å­¦ä¹ å¾ˆå¿«åº”ç”¨äºå„ç§æ–°äº§å“å’ŒæœåŠ¡ä¸­ã€‚Amazon çš„ Alexa ç­‰è¯­éŸ³é©±åŠ¨è®¾å¤‡é—®ä¸–ã€‚åœ¨çº¿è½¬å½•æœåŠ¡å˜å¾—å®ç”¨ã€‚ç½‘ç»œæµè§ˆå™¨æä¾›è‡ªåŠ¨ç¿»è¯‘ã€‚è¯´è¿™äº›é¡¹ç›®ç”± AI èµ‹èƒ½å¬èµ·æ¥å¾ˆé…·ï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯ä»¤äººå°´å°¬ï¼Œå°½ç®¡è¿™ä¹Ÿæœ‰ç‚¹å¤šä½™ï¼›å½“æ—¶å’Œç°åœ¨ï¼Œå‡ ä¹æ‰€æœ‰è¢«ç§°ä¸ºäººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½çš„æŠ€æœ¯å®é™…ä¸Šéƒ½ä¾èµ–äºæ·±åº¦å­¦ä¹ ã€‚

transcription n. æŠ„å†™ï¼›èªŠå†™
redundant adj. å¤šä½™çš„ï¼›è¿‡å‰©çš„
bonnet n. è½¯å¸½ï¼›é˜€å¸½ï¼›å¼•æ“ç›–
under the bonnet åœ¨å†…éƒ¨ï¼› åœ¨èƒŒå

ChatgptÂ and its rivals really do seem to â€œuse language and form abstractionsâ€ ChatGPTåŠå…¶ç«äº‰å¯¹æ‰‹ç¡®å®ä¼¼ä¹èƒ½å¤Ÿ â€œä½¿ç”¨è¯­è¨€å¹¶å½¢æˆæŠ½è±¡æ¦‚å¿µâ€

In 2017 a qualitative change was added to the quantitative benefits being provided by more computing power and more data: a new way of arranging connections between neurons called the transformer. Transformers enable neural networks to keep track of patterns in their input, even if the elements of the pattern are far apart, in a way that allows them to bestow â€œattentionâ€ on particular features in the data.

2017 å¹´ï¼Œæ›´å¼ºå¤§çš„è®¡ç®—èƒ½åŠ›å’Œæ›´å¤šçš„æ•°æ®æ‰€å¸¦æ¥çš„æ•°é‡æ•ˆç›Šå‘ç”Ÿäº†è´¨çš„å˜åŒ–ï¼šä¸€ç§å®‰æ’ç¥ç»å…ƒä¹‹é—´è¿æ¥çš„æ–°æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œç§°ä¸ºâ€œTransformerâ€ã€‚Transformer ä½¿ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œèƒ½å¤Ÿè·Ÿè¸ªè¾“å…¥ä¸­çš„æ¨¡å¼ï¼Œå³ä½¿æ¨¡å¼ä¸­çš„å…ƒç´ ç›¸è·å¾ˆè¿œï¼Œä¹Ÿèƒ½ä»¥æŸç§æ–¹å¼è®©å®ƒä»¬å¯¹æ•°æ®ä¸­çš„ç‰¹å®šç‰¹å¾ç»™äºˆâ€œæ³¨æ„åŠ›â€ã€‚

rival n. ç«äº‰è€…ï¼›æ•Œæ‰‹ ï½œ v. ç«äº‰

qualitative change è´¨å˜

bestow â€¦ on phrase. ç»™äºˆï¼›èµ äºˆï¼›æˆäºˆ

Transformers gave networks a better grasp of context, which suited them to a technique called â€œself-supervised learningâ€. In essence, some words are randomly blanked out during training, and the model teaches itself to fill in the most likely candidate. Because the training data do not have to be labelled in advance, such models can be trained using billions of words of raw text taken from the internet.

Transformer è®©ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œæ›´å¥½æŠ“ä½ä¸Šä¸‹æ–‡ï¼Œè¿™è®©å®ƒä»¬æ›´é€‚åˆä¸€é¡¹ç§°ä¸ºâ€œè‡ªç›‘ç®¡å­¦ä¹ â€çš„æŠ€æœ¯ã€‚æœ¬è´¨ä¸Šï¼Œåœ¨è®­ç»ƒè¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­ï¼Œä¸€äº›å•è¯ä¼šè¢«éšæœºåˆ é™¤ï¼Œç„¶åæ¨¡å‹ä¼šè‡ªå­¦å¡«å†™æœ€æœ‰å¯èƒ½çš„å€™é€‰å•è¯ã€‚ç”±äºè®­ç»ƒæ•°æ®ä¸éœ€è¦æå‰æ ‡è®°ï¼Œå› æ­¤è¿™äº›æ¨¡å‹å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨ä»äº’è”ç½‘ä¸Šè·å–çš„æ•°åäº¿å­—çš„åŸå§‹æ–‡æœ¬æ¥è®­ç»ƒã€‚

in advance phrase. æå‰
raw adj. ç”Ÿçš„ï¼›æœªç»å¤„ç†çš„

Mind Your Language Model å…³æ³¨ä½ çš„è¯­è¨€æ¨¡å‹

Transformer-based large language models (LLMs) began attracting wider attention in 2019, when a model called GPT-2 was released by OpenAI, a startup (GPT stands for generative pre-trained transformer). Such LLMs turned out to be capable of â€œemergentâ€ behaviour for which they had not been explicitly trained. Soaking up huge amounts of language did not just make them surprisingly adept at linguistic tasks like summarisation or translation, but also at thingsâ€”like simple arithmetic and the writing of softwareâ€”which were implicit in the training data. Less happily it also meant they reproduced biases in the data fed to them, which meant many of the prevailing prejudices of human society emerged in their output.

åŸºäº Transformer çš„å¤§è¯­è¨€æ¨¡å‹åœ¨ 2019 å¹´å¼€å§‹å—åˆ°å¹¿æ³›å…³æ³¨ï¼Œå½“æ—¶ä¸€ä¸ªç”±åˆåˆ›å…¬å¸ OpenAI å‘å¸ƒäº†åä¸º GPT-2ï¼ˆGPT ä»£è¡¨ ç”Ÿæˆå¼é¢„è®­ç»ƒ Transformerï¼‰ çš„æ¨¡å‹ã€‚è¿™äº› LLM èƒ½å¤Ÿè¡¨ç°å‡º â€œemergentâ€ è¡Œä¸ºï¼Œå°½ç®¡ä»–ä»¬æ›¾ç»æ²¡æœ‰æ¥å—è¿‡ä¸“é—¨çš„è®­ç»ƒã€‚å¸æ”¶å¤§é‡çš„è¯­æ–™ä¸ä»…ä½¿å®ƒä»¬å‡ºäººæ„æ–™åœ°æ“…é•¿è¯­è¨€å­¦ä»»åŠ¡ï¼ˆæ¯”å¦‚æ€»ç»“æˆ–ç¿»è¯‘ï¼‰ï¼Œè€Œä¸”è¿˜æ“…é•¿è®­ç»ƒæ•°æ®ä¸­éšå«çš„äº‹æƒ…ï¼ˆæ¯”å¦‚ç®€å•çš„ç®—æœ¯å’Œè½¯ä»¶ç¼–å†™ï¼‰ã€‚ä½†ä¸å¹¸çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œè¿™ä¹Ÿæ„å‘³ç€å®ƒä»¬åœ¨è¾“å…¥çš„æ•°æ®ä¸­é‡ç°äº†åè§ï¼Œè¿™æ„å‘³ç€äººç±»ç¤¾ä¼šè®¸å¤šæ™®éçš„åè§éƒ½å‡ºç°åœ¨å®ƒä»¬çš„è¾“å‡ºä¸­ã€‚

stand for phrase. ä»£è¡¨ï¼›è±¡å¾ï¼›æ”¯æŒï¼›å®¹å¿
turn out to be phrase. ç»“æœæ˜¯ï¼›åŸæ¥æ˜¯ï¼›è¯å®æ˜¯

prejudice n. åè§ï¼›æˆè§ ï½œ v. ä½¿æœ‰åè§ï¼›æŸå®³

In November 2022 a larger OpenAI model, GPT-3.5, was presented to the public in the form of a chatbot. Anyone with a web browser could enter a prompt and get a response. No consumer product has ever taken off quicker. Within weeks ChatGPT was generating everything from college essays to computer code. AI had made another great leap forward.

2022 å¹´ 11 æœˆï¼Œæ›´å¤§çš„ OpenAI æ¨¡å‹ GPT-3.5 ä»¥èŠå¤©æœºå™¨äººçš„å½¢å¼å‘å…¬ä¼—å…¬å¼€ã€‚ä»»ä½•æ‹¥æœ‰ç½‘ç»œæµè§ˆå™¨çš„äººéƒ½å¯ä»¥è¾“å…¥ prompt å¹¶è·å¾—å“åº”ã€‚ä»æ¥æ²¡æœ‰ä»»ä½•æ¶ˆè´¹äº§å“èƒ½å¤Ÿåƒå®ƒä¸€æ ·è¿…é€Ÿæµè¡Œã€‚å‘å¸ƒåçš„çŸ­çŸ­å‡ å‘¨å†…ï¼ŒChatGPT å°±å±•ç°å‡ºäº†å®ƒå¼ºå¤§çš„ç”Ÿæˆèƒ½åŠ›ï¼Œæ¶µç›–äº†ä»å­¦æœ¯å†™ä½œåˆ°ç¼–ç¨‹ç­‰å¤šä¸ªé¢†åŸŸã€‚äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½åˆä¸€æ¬¡å®ç°äº†å·¨å¤§çš„é£è·ƒã€‚

take off phrase. çªç„¶æˆåŠŸï¼›æ‹¿æ‰ï¼›ç¦»å¼€ï¼›èµ·é£ï¼›è„±ä¸‹
within weeks çŸ­çŸ­å‡ å‘¨å†…
another great leap forward åˆä¸€æ¬¡å·¨å¤§çš„é£è·ƒ

Where the first cohort of AI-powered products was based on recognition, this second one is based on generation. Deep-learning models such as Stable Diffusion and DALL-E, which also made their debuts around that time, used a technique called diffusion to turn text prompts into images. Other models can produce surprisingly realistic video, speech or music.

ç¬¬ä¸€æ‰¹ AI èµ‹èƒ½äº§å“åŸºäºè¯†åˆ«ï¼Œè€Œç¬¬äºŒæ‰¹åˆ™åŸºäºç”Ÿæˆã€‚Stable Diffusion å’Œ DALL-E ç­‰æ·±åº¦å­¦ä¹ æ¨¡å‹ä¹Ÿæ˜¯åœ¨é‚£æ—¶é¦–æ¬¡äº®ç›¸ï¼Œå®ƒä»¬ä½¿ç”¨ä¸€ç§ç§°ä¸º diffusion çš„æŠ€æœ¯å°†æ–‡æœ¬ prompt è½¬æ¢ä¸ºå›¾åƒã€‚å…¶ä»–æ¨¡å‹å¯ä»¥åˆ¶ä½œå‡ºä»¤äººæƒŠè®¶çš„é€¼çœŸçš„è§†é¢‘ã€è¯­éŸ³æˆ–éŸ³ä¹ã€‚

around that time åœ¨é‚£ä¸ªæ—¶å€™ï¼›å¤§çº¦åœ¨åŒä¸€æ—¶é—´
diffusion n. æ‰©æ•£ï¼›ä¼ æ’­ï¼›æ¼«æ•£

The leap is not just technological. Making things makes a difference. ChatGPT and rivals such as Gemini (from Google) and Claude (from Anthropic, founded by researchers previously at OpenAI) produce outputs from calculations just as other deep-learning systems do. But the fact that they respond to requests with novelties makes them feel very unlike software which recognises faces, takes dictation or translates menus. They really do seem to â€œuse languageâ€ and â€œform abstractionsâ€, just as McCarthy had hoped.

è¿™ç§é£è·ƒä¸ä»…ä»…æ˜¯æŠ€æœ¯ä¸Šçš„ã€‚åˆ›é€ èƒ½å¤Ÿå¸¦æ¥æ”¹å˜ã€‚ChatGPT ä»¥åŠå®ƒçš„ç«äº‰å¯¹æ‰‹ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚æ¥è‡ª Google çš„ Gemini å’Œ Anthropicï¼ˆç”±å‰ OpenAI ç ”ç©¶äººå‘˜åˆ›ç«‹çš„å…¬å¸ï¼‰çš„Claude é€šè¿‡è®¡ç®—ç”Ÿæˆè¾“å‡ºï¼Œè¿™ä¹Ÿåƒå…¶ä»–æ·±åº¦å­¦ä¹ ç³»ç»Ÿä¸€æ ·ã€‚ä½†å®ƒä»¬é€šè¿‡æ–°é¢–çš„æ–¹å¼å›åº”è¯·æ±‚è¿™ä¸€äº‹å®ï¼Œä½¿å®ƒä»¬çœ‹èµ·æ¥éå¸¸ä¸åŒäºé‚£äº›è¯†åˆ«äººè„¸ã€è¿›è¡Œè¯­éŸ³è½¬è¯‘æˆ–ç¿»è¯‘èœå•çš„è½¯ä»¶ã€‚å®ƒä»¬ä¼¼ä¹ç¡®å®åœ¨ â€œä½¿ç”¨è¯­è¨€â€ å’Œ â€œå½¢æˆæŠ½è±¡æ¦‚å¿µâ€ï¼Œæ­£å¦‚ McCarthy æ‰€å¸Œæœ›çš„é‚£æ ·ã€‚

Making things makes a difference. åˆ›é€ èƒ½å¤Ÿå¸¦æ¥æ”¹å˜ã€‚

This series of briefs will look at how these models work, how much further their powers can grow, what new uses they will be put to, as well as what they will not, or should not, be used for. â–
